repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Problem: The codelens module displays lenses as virtual text. Because extmarks are set in the local display_line_lenses function, this cannot be changed directly. Proposed solution: Create a display option in the codelens module that allows configuring which extmarks are set. Add code to support virtual lines. Questions: - ~~Is this the best design pattern to achieve this goal? I based it on vim.lsp.log.get_level() and set_level(). I wanted to avoid exposing more of the module's internals in the name of achieving a simple end result~~ - ~~Is CodeLensDisplay the best naming choice for the opts table?~~ - ~~Is the validation/annotation for hl_mode done in the best way? It's a direct copy of what's in the vim.api.keyset.set_extmark annotation, but would also have to be manually edited if the API changed~~

comment_data.body: This makes me thing a callback might fit better. If we are just forwarding parameters to `nvim_buf_set_extmark` that's a signal that maybe the user can define a function that calls `nvim_buf_set_extmark` or whatever.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1938,6 +1938,20 @@ Client:supports_method({method}, {bufnr})           *Client:supports_method()*
 ==============================================================================
 Lua module: vim.lsp.codelens                                    *lsp-codelens*
 
+*vim.lsp.codelens.display.Opts*
+    Display options for lenses
+
+    Fields: ~
+      • {extmark_params}  (`vim.api.keyset.set_extmark`) See

comment_data.body: this is yet another way of configuring stuff. look for existing patterns. we have `vim.foo.config` for various things, that's one way. the other common mechanism is `enable(..., {opts})`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1997,6 +2017,14 @@ save({lenses}, {bufnr}, {client_id})                 *vim.lsp.codelens.save()*
       • {bufnr}      (`integer`)
       • {client_id}  (`integer`)
 
+set_display({opts})                           *vim.lsp.codelens.set_display()*
+    Sets display options for lenses

@@ -1964,6 +1978,12 @@ get({bufnr})                                          *vim.lsp.codelens.get()*
     Return: ~
         (`lsp.CodeLens[]`)
 
+get_display()                                 *vim.lsp.codelens.get_display()*
+    Gets current display options for lenses

comment_data.body: Could use config(), and have a nil opts table return return the current config the way vim.diagnostic does. This would also resolve the comment on get_display()
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1997,6 +2017,14 @@ save({lenses}, {bufnr}, {client_id})                 *vim.lsp.codelens.save()*
       • {bufnr}      (`integer`)
       • {client_id}  (`integer`)
 
+set_display({opts})                           *vim.lsp.codelens.set_display()*
+    Sets display options for lenses

comment_data.body: Can do this like the diagnostic module, where you can either enter a boolean or a callback function. Would save a bunch of guard code.

comment_regular_data.body:
UPDATE:

- ~~In line with vim.lsp.codelens.refresh.Opts, renamed the display opts to vim.lsp.codelens.display.Opts~~
- Added annotations and re-built docs
- ~~Still unsure of how to handle the hl_mode option. An alternative could be to allow for passing in an entire extmark opts table, then letting display_line_lenses add the options it needs to using a table extend. The upside - very extensible and hackable. The downsides - Might be a lot to throw at an inexperienced user, and the errors on a malformed keyset would be brutal~~

> screenshot? > > is there an open issue for this? This is how the virtual line display looks in my setup: No open issue that I'm aware of. But since I had hacked a version of it together for myself, wanted to try building it out.

put the screenshot in the top description :) 

I think the idea makes sense, but the set_display/get_display is probably not the right interface.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(codelens): display as virtual lines (instead of virtual text)
